reviewText: This is another soap opera series, nominally about the UK's SAS 22nd Regiment. If you like quasi-realistic drama and English accents and men running about in black kit, this could be the diversion you've been looking for. Or, if you're an armchair critic you can have fun playing "spot the inaccuracies" and keeping score of how many there are per episode (the episode with the highest number of course passing this tough selection). Remember: who stares, wins.As you can tell, I'm rather ambiguous about the exploitative nature of this series. It depends on people "wanting to know" about the Special Air Service; yet at the same time much of the "detail" is necessarily misdirection. It's like those endless movie car-chase scenes where instead of getting behind the car you want to force off the road and hitting it on one side (e.g. a blow to the left-rear of the vehicle in front will sent it off the road to the right) you pull alongside and go front-to-front. Makes for a stock movie cliche but it's not realistic in any sense of the word because they don't want you to try this at home. Which leaves us with a conundrum: the series relies on its apparent "realism" as a key selling point yet that realism is actually bogus. So we're left with the drama, the soap opera, and frankly it's a bit mechanical - could definitely do better in the tell-us-a-yarn department.And personally if I see one more "sniper" sequence where the gun barrel is protruding through an open window or a parted curtain so as to be visible to anyone with a decent pair of binos I think I'll... watch something else instead.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Joseph Kohout Jr. "The Art of War"
reviewText: Seasons 1 & 2 are superior; however, I actually prefer the action that takes place outside the UK. A contrast for sure.The writing is not as tight as it could have been, especially re: the first episode of season 3 where 3-major and several minor characters were either killed off (in one scene) or disappeared with feeble explanations (I.E. "I had to get rid of her, as I couldn't have her mooning about").Reminiscent of the US show "The Unit" which seems to have "borrowed" the plot formula with a bit more emphasis on the family relationship angle. If you like "Ultimate Force", you should like "The Unit".For those of you with a Region Free DVR (and if you don't have one, why not?), do your self a favor and purchase on Amazon.com/UK for +-$30 including shipping for 4-seasons.  This is an absolute bargain!
summary: If You Like "The Unit" USA - You Will Love "Ultimate Force" -UK

reviewText: this show is kind of like watching someone else play call of duty.  i am a girl and i dont play video games, but for some reason i love this show.  i call it my guilty pleasure. its illogical and absurd but its fun.  in the first episode of one of the seasons, 4 main characters are just gone.  they mention in passing they died and one was reassigned, but they dont seem to mind...no one is in mourning and they were the MAIN CHARACTERS.  this show is just great when you are sick and dont really want to think about it.  but half the time i wanted harry pearce to show up and force these guys to start making sense.

reviewText: With Ross Kemp (EastEnders) starring as Staff Sergeant Henry "Henno" Garvie, the British TV show Ultra Force (2002-08) follows the exploits of a small elite SAS (Special Air Service) unit, designated as Red Troop.  These specially trained soldiers handle a wide variety of situations, both domestic and foreign, including hostage situations, counterterrorist operations, and combat operations in faraway lands.  The stories generally have few dull moments, and almost always involve extreme and brutal violence, as when unleashed, Red Troop attempts to destroy the enemy or neutralize a threat, with extreme prejudice, rarely leaving any of the opposition breathing.  An action based drama, featuring a variety of situations and military tactics, Ultra Force hits hard, with a brutal "take no prisoners" attitude, that is not for the faint hearted.Tough, disciplined, and completely dedicated to the job, Sergeant Garvie appears in every episode, and up until Series 4, is in immediate command of Red Troop in the field.  Garvie works under the command of several superior officers, but most often answers to Colonel Aidan Dempsey (Miles Anderson), the capable and pragmatic regiment commander, who also takes political considerations into account.  In Series 4, Colonel Dempsey appoints an officer, Captain Fleming (Sam Callis), as field commander of Red Troop.The program can be divided into two distinct "eras", each with a fairly stable but different cast.  Series 1 and 2 features one group of Red Troop members, but at the start of Series 3, several of them are killed or replaced, as Ultimate Force undergoes a massive "reset" where many previous storylines, including Garvie's execution of one of his own men, are never addressed.  While in the beginning, there are attempts to integrate elements of the soldier's personal and romantic lives, these kinds of diversions basically cease after Series 2, and the focus turns mainly to the missions, and if anything, the level of violence seems to escalate.  While these developments may be troubling for some, those mainly interested in the action aspects may be more accepting of the changes.  The inclusion of a female, Becca Gallagher (Heather Peace), to Red Troop in Series 3, adds interest and story options, without sacrificing any of the action elements.While the violence is occasionally unrealistic or completely over the top, most times the stories hold up fairly well, with the opposition, be they criminals, terrorists, or an armed force, usually behaving in a credible manner.  Red Troop works well under fire, or in high pressure situations, with each member fulfilling their assigned role.  Except for the cast revamp in Series 3, the unit manages to keep casualties and injuries to a minimum.  Continuity between the episodes is typically not a major concern, as several times a team member who is shot, returns in the next episode completely healed, and no worse for wear.High points include "Slow Bomb", where terrorist threaten to explode a dirty bomb in London, and "Deadlier Than The Male", where terrorists have taken over a plane.  "Violent Solutions" has Red Troop after weapons and drug dealers, and "Wannabes" features the unit on the trail of a group of suicide bombers.While CBS's series The Unit may be the closest American equivalent, Ultimate Force is far more violent, with soldiers routinely killing the wounded.  Nudity is also featured, and while there is initially some romantic drama, it does not come close to the melodramatic storylines involving the wives of soldiers, featured in The Unit.This Region 2 eight DVD set, contains the 21 episodes produced in Series 1 through 4 of Ultimate Force.  For those unfamiliar with British television, the term "series" is equivalent to "season" for American TV.  Series 1 and 2 contain six episodes, Series 3 has four, and Series 4 has five.  Be advised, you will need a region free player to view the DVD's.  If the cost is too high, you may find a better deal ordering from Amazon.UK.While there are a few missteps and misfires in the story department, Ultimate Force is still an entertaining and very exciting program, which explores a number of provocative scenarios, in some interesting locations.  If the activities of the real SAS span the world to this extent, it could be a little scary.  The excessive violence certainly isn't for everyone, but as drama centered on military special forces and tactical operations, Ultimate Force definitely delivers the goods, and is a program that would surely be more popular in America, if only more were aware of its existence.
summary: violent, brutal, and uncompromising...death usually awaits those who oppose Red Troop
